Description: THIS PROPOSAL IS A COOPERATIVE TAGGING PROJECT AIMED AT ENHANCING THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACT OF RECREATIONAL FISHING ON BULL SHARKS. THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE WORKING CLOSELY WITH CHARTER CAPTAINS THROUGHOUT THE U.S. SOUTH ATLANTIC AND THE GULF OF MEXICO TO CAPTURE AND SATELLITE TAG SHARKS. CAPTURE INFORMATION AND TAG-DERIVED MOVEMENT DATA WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE PRM IN THE RECREATIONAL FISHERY AND IDENTIFY THE CAPTURE CHARACTERISTICS (I.E., FISHING CONDITIONS AND PRACTICES AND BIOLOGICAL TRAITS) DRIVING THE RECOVERY AND MORTALITY OF SHARKS DISCARDED IN THIS FISHERY. THE INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BE AN IMPORTANT, PROACTIVE STEP TOWARD PROPERLY MANAGING BULL SHARKS AND IS PARTICULARLY TIMELY GIVEN THIS SPECIES' UPCOMING STOCK ASSESSMENT.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE THE LIFE HISTORY OF BULL SHARKS IN THE NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO AND U.S. SOUTH ATLANTIC TO GENERATE UPDATED LIFE HISTORY PARAMETERS NECESSARY FOR CONTINUED MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY OF THIS SPECIES. SPECIFICALLY, THIS STUDY WILL COLLECT IMMATURE AND MATURE BULL SHARKS ON A MONTHLY BASIS TO FULLY DESCRIBE THE SEASONAL REPRODUCTIVE BIOLOGY OF THIS SPECIES AND PROVIDE UPDATED AGE AND GROWTH ESTIMATES.

THE PROPOSED WORK WITH THE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY FOUNDATION WILL MAINTAIN A UNIQUE SET OF PROGRAMS WHERE THE GOALS OF FISHERIES AND SANCTUARIES INTERSECT. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT EDUCATORS IN A WIDE-RANGE OF ACTIVITIES SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED FOR THEM TO BRING OCEAN SCIENCE EXPERIENCES TO THE TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS THROUGH THE UNIQUE TEACHER AT SEA ALUMNI ASSOCIATION. FISHERMEN BETTER UNDERSTAND AND NAVIGATE THE COMPLEX WORLD OF FEDERAL REGULATION THROUGH THEIR EDUCATION PROGRAM DIRECTLY SUPPORTING FISHERMEN'S NEEDS AND FISHERIES REGULATION. THE PROJECT WILL CONVENE STAKEHOLDERS IN OCEAN AND GREAT LAKES ISSUES THROUGH THEIR SIGNATURE CAPITOL HILL OCEAN WEEK SYMPOSIUM, WHERE ISSUES ON U.S. SEAFOOD SUSTAINABILITY ARE OFTEN BROUGHT TO THE FOREFRONT. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ENGAGE PARTNERS THROUGH COMPETITIVE GRANTS THAT WERE ADAPTED TO SUPPORT EDUCATION AND COMMUNICATIONS PARTNERSHIPS THAT BUILD AWARENESS OF THE PLIGHT OF ENDANGERED AND PROTECTED MARINE SPECIES, AS WELL AS OTHER PRO

QUIET SOUND, A PROGRAM OF THE NONPROFIT WASHINGTON MARITIME BLUE (ALSO REFERRED TO AS
MARITIME BLUE), AIMS TO UNDERSTAND AND MITIGATE THE ACOUSTIC AND PHYSICAL IMPACTS OF LARGE
COMMERCIAL VESSELS ON ENDANGERED SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES (SRKW) IN THEIR CRITICAL
HABITAT IN WASHINGTON WATERS. QUIET SOUND SEEKS TO ENGAGE THE PEOPLE IN WASHINGTON'S MARITIME
SECTOR WHO RUN, CREW, PILOT, OWN AND ADMINISTER LARGE COMMERCIAL VESSELS IN AN ANNUAL VOLUNTARY
PROGRAM TO TAKE PROTECTIVE MEASURES FOR SOUTHERN RESIDENT KILLER WHALES. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS
OUTREACH PROGRAM IS TO EMPOWER VESSEL OPERATORS TO AVOID SHIP STRIKES AND MITIGATE ACOUSTIC
IMPACTS. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT SRKW CONSERVATION EFFORTS BY:
1) DEVELOPING VOLUNTARY VESSEL MEASURES WITH THE ENGAGEMENT AND SUPPORT OF THE MARITIME
SECTOR
2) EDUCATING VESSEL PILOTS, CREW, MASTERS, OPERATION CENTERS, AGENTS, AND OWNERS ON WHAT
LARGE VESSELS CAN DO ON THE WATER TO BE SAFER FOR WHALES
3) TRACKING PARTICIPATION RATES FOR ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THE PROGRAM OVER TIME
4) RECOGNIZING PARTICIPATION TO BUILD GREATER ENGAGEMENT FOR EACH ANNUAL CYCLE
THROUGH THIS FOUR-YEAR PROJECT, WE WILL REACH OUR OBJECTIVE OF AN EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION PLAN
THAT ENABLES VESSEL OPERATORS TO ACT IN SUPPORT OF SRKWS, AND WE WILL BE WORKING TOWARD OUR
OVERALL GOAL OF REDUCING THE ACOUSTIC IMPACT OF LARGE VESSELS ON ENDANGERED KILLER WHALES IN
WASHINGTON STATE WATERS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS NOAA'S 2021 SPECIES IN THE SPOTLIGHT ACTION
PLAN FOR SRKW BY PROTECTING KILLER WHALES FROM HARMFUL VESSEL IMPACTS THROUGH EDUCATION.

KILLER WHALES ARE AMONG THE MOST FASCINATING AND CHARISMATIC SPECIES IN THE
PACIFIC NORTHWEST. WHILE THEIR POPULARITY DRAWS A LOT OF ATTENTION TO THEIR BIOLOGY AND
DELICATE CONSERVATION STATUS, THE SOLUTIONS FOR RECOVERY ARE OFTEN MUNDANE AND
OVERLOOKED. WHALE SCOUT HARNESSES THE ADMIRATION AND ENERGY OF WHALE WATCHERS AND
DIVERSE COMMUNITY GROUPS, CHANNELING IT TOWARDS NATIVE PLANTS, STREAMS, AND FORESTS.
KILLER WHALES ACT AS A POWERFUL LEAD-IN TO FURTHER INQUIRIES ABOUT SALMON, AND THE
FUNCTIONS OF THE WATERSHEDS AND RIPARIAN ZONES THAT SUPPORT THEM. WE OFFER EDUCATIONAL
LAND-BASED WHALE WATCHING AND HANDS-ON EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES RESTORING
CHINOOK SALMON HABITAT, DRAWING DIRECT CONNECTIONS BETWEEN WHALES, SALMON, AND
HEALTHY STREAMS. OUTCOMES OF THIS EDUCATIONAL WORK ALSO OFFER DIRECT BENEFITS, IMPROVING
WATER QUALITY IN OUR OWN NEIGHBORHOODS AND LEADING TO INCREASED SURVIVAL RATES FOR
SALMON AND KILLER WHALES. OUR ULTIMATE GOAL IS TO RECOVER THE ENDANGERED SOUTHERN
RESIDENT COMMUNITY OF KILLER WHALES, WHICH NOW NUMBERS JUST 74 ANIMALS. WHALE SCOUT
IS STRIVING TO ACCOMPLISH THIS BY EDUCATING AND ACTIVATING LARGE COMMUNITIES OF WHALE
WATCHERS AND DIVERSE LOCAL GROUPS TO ENGAGE IN SALMON HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AND
EVERYDAY STEWARDSHIP ACTIONS.

IN 2017, NOAA PUBLISHED THE ROCKFISH RECOVERY PLAN FOR PUGET SOUND/GEORGIA BASIN YELLOWEYE ROCKFISH (SEBASTES RUBERRIMUS) AND BOCACCIO (SEBASTES PAUCISPINIS) FOR ESA-LISTED POPULATIONS OCCUPYING THE SALISH SEA. THIS RECOVERY PLAN OUTLINES ACTIONS AND RESEARCH FOR THE CONSERVATION AND SURVIVAL OF THREATENED YELLOWEYE ROCKFISH AND ENDANGERED BOCACCIO USING THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE, PER THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA).  WHILE HATCHERY AND AQUACULTURE RESTORATION EFFORTS ARE NOT IDENTIFIED IN THE PLAN, IT ACKNOWLEDGES THAT AN INCOMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF HABITAT AND PREY NEEDS AT CRITICAL LIFE STAGES MAY LIMIT THE EFFECTIVENESS OF RECOVERY EFFORTS. CURRENTLY, KNOWLEDGE OF DEVELOPMENT, DIETARY NEEDS, AND GROWTH RATES ARE BASED ON OBSERVATIONS IN THE WILD, AND ARE LARGELY BASED ON POST-SETTLEMENT LIFE STAGES. LIKE MANY MARINE FISH SPECIES, HOWEVER, ROCKFISH EXPERIENCE SUBSTANTIAL MORTALITY RATES AS LARVAE, AND UNDERSTANDING EARLY LIFE HISTORY DYNAMICS IS KEY TO EFFECT

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) SEEKS FUNDING TO PROVIDE NORTH CENTRAL REGION STAFFING SUPPORT FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF HATCHERY AND GENETIC MANAGEMENT PLANS (HGMP) FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CENTRAL VALLEY SPRING-RUN AND FALL-RUN CHINOOK SALMON AND CENTRAL VALLEY STEELHEAD TROUT AT THE FEATHER RIVER AND MOKELUMNE RIVER FISH HATCHERIES. ADDITIONALLY, CDFW SEEKS FUNDING TO PROVIDE STAFFING SUPPORT FOR THE COORDINATION AND DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF HGMPS STATEWIDE.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE DEDICATED EFFORT TOWARDS THE COLLECTION OF ESA-LISTED BOCACCIO ROCKFISH SAMPLES IN PUGET SOUND, WASHINGTON. FIN CLIP SAMPLES WILL BE TAKEN FROM CAPTURED FISH USING NON-LETHAL METHODS AND WILL BE PROVIDED TO GENETICISTS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON AS PART OF A BROADER EFFORT TO DELINEATE DISCRETE POPULATIONS OF THIS SPECIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSAL IS TO MANAGE, ENHANCE, RESTORE AND MAINTAIN THE SHARED FISHERIES, PROTECTED SPECIES AND FISHERIES HABITAT OF THE US ATLANTIC COAST.  THIS PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT THE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF MARINE FISHERY RESOURCES AND THEIR HABITAT, AS WELL AS THE MAINTENANCE, ENHANCEMENT, AND IMPROVEMENT OF PUBLIC USES AND BENEFITS FROM THESE RESOURCES, INCLUDING SEAFOOD PRODUCTION, RECREATION, AND COMMERCE.  ASMFC STAFF WILL WORK TO SUPPORT SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING:  1) PROVIDE SERVICES AND RESEARCH SUPPORT FOR LIVING MARINE RESOURCES MANAGEMENT AND ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES RELATING TO FISHERY STAKEHOLDERS CONSISTENT WITH THE MISSION OF NOAA FISHERIES; 2) COORDINATE TRAININGS, WORKSHOPS AND MEETINGS TO GATHER AND CONVEY INFORMATION RELATED TO FISHERIES, PROTECTED SPECIES AND HABIT MANAGEMENT; 3) COLLECT, ANALYZE, AND MAINTAIN FISHERIES, PROTECTED SPECIES AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT DATA 4) SUPPORT REGIONAL AQUACULTURE SCIENCE AND MARINE COOPE

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSAL IS TO MANAGE, ENHANCE, RESTORE AND MAINTAIN THE SHARED FISHERIES, PROTECTED SPECIES AND FISHERIES HABITAT OF THE US COAST.  THIS PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT THE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF MARINE FISHERY RESOURCES AND THEIR HABITAT, AS WELL AS THE MAINTENANCE, ENHANCEMENT, AND IMPROVEMENT OF PUBLIC USES AND BENEFITS FROM THESE RESOURCES, INCLUDING SEAFOOD PRODUCTION, RECREATION, AND COMMERCE.  PSMFC STAFF WILL WORK TO SUPPORT SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING:  1) PROVIDE SERVICES AND RESEARCH SUPPORT FOR LIVING MARINE RESOURCES MANAGEMENT AND ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES RELATING TO FISHERY STAKEHOLDERS CONSISTENT WITH THE MISSION OF NOAA FISHERIES; 2) COORDINATE TRAININGS, WORKSHOPS AND MEETINGS TO GATHER AND CONVEY INFORMATION RELATED TO FISHERIES, PROTECTED SPECIES AND HABIT MANAGEMENT; 3) COLLECT, ANALYZE, AND MAINTAIN FISHERIES, PROTECTED SPECIES AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT DATA 4) SUPPORT REGIONAL AQUACULTURE SCIENCE AND MARINE COOPERATIVE PR

HAWKSBILL SEA TURTLES (ERETMOCHELYS IMBRICATA) ARE AMONG THE RAREST SEA TURTLES IN THE PACIFIC OCEAN AND ARE CLASSIFIED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND CRITICALLY ENDANGERED BY THE INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR CONSERVATION OF NATURE. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE HAWAII ISLAND HAWKSBILL PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, PROTECTION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF HAWKSBILL SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS AND THEIR NESTING HABITATS IN HAWAII BY CARRYING OUT RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION ACTIVITES AT THE MOST IMPORTANT NESTING HABITATS ALONG THE SOUTHERN COAST OF HAWAII ISLAND. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: 1) MONITORING NESTING BEACHES TO IDENTIFY AND QUANTIFY NESTING FEMALES AND NESTS; 2) DETERMINING HATCHING SUCCESS AND HATCHLING PRODUCTION AND PROTECT NESTS TO MAXIMIZE THE NUMBER OF HATCHLINGS THAT SAFELY REACH THE OCEAN; 3) CONTROLLING NON-NATIVE SPECIES ON NESTING BEACHES TO REDUCE PREDATION ON NESTS, EGGS AND HATCHLINGS; 4) PROVIDING IMPROVED NESTING HABITAT

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING FUNDING TO THE MAUI OCEAN CENTER MARINE INSTITUTE (MOCMI) FOR THE PROJECT ENTITLED "SEA TURTLE MANAGEMENT SUPPORT, FIELD RESPONSE, AND OUTREACH ON MAUI". MOCMI  PROVIDES A COMPREHENSIVE SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM ON THE ISLAND OF MAUI. THROUGH SUPPORT FROM THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY MOCMI WILL RESPOND TO REPORTS OF SICK, INJURED, DISTRESSED, OR OTHERWISE COMPROMISED SEA TURTLES. USING THE DATA OBTAINED THROUGH STRANDING RESPONSE, MOCMI AIMS TO IMPROVE ISSUE UNDERSTANDING WITHIN THE COMMUNITY AND REDUCE THREATS IMPACTING SEA TURTLES BY ESTABLISHING EASILY ADAPTABLE CONSERVATION INITIATIVE AND ACCESSIBLE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW MOCMI TO INCREASE SEA TURTLE STRANDING RESPONSE CAPABILITIES AND EXPAND COMMUNITY EDUCATION AND OUTREACH EFFORTS.

FOR THIS PROPOSAL WE WOULD FOCUS ON EXAMINING THE TEMPORAL OCCURRENCE OF WHALES ON THEIR BREEDING GROUNDS. WE WOULD EXAMINE TWO METRICS: 1) THE PROPORTION OF WHALES GOING TO KEY FEEDING AREAS OFF THE US WEST COAST AND FARTHER NORTH, AND 2) THE PROPORTION OF WHALES IN MEXICO MATCHING TO WHALES KNOWN TO GO THE CENTRAL AMERICA. THESE RESULTS WOULD BE COMPARED THROUGH THE WINTER BREEDING SEASON IN MEXICO.   WHILE INITIALLY EFFORTS FOCUSED ON IDENTIFYING THE SPATIAL SEPARATION BETWEEN THE MEXICO AND CENTRAL AMERICA DPS', THE RESULTS MENTIONED ABOVE INDICATE THAT CONSIDERING THE TIMING OF OCCURRENCE MAY HELP IN MAKING THE SEPARATION BETWEEN THESE. WE WOULD LARGELY RELY ON EXISTING DATA ALREADY GATHERED THAT CAN HELP ADDRESS THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ESPECIALLY FROM THE 2021 AND 2022 WINTER SEASONS WHERE THE NOAA SUPPORT HAS ALREADY PROVIDED OUR BEST SAMPLE SIZE OF WHALES FROM S MEXICO AND CENTRAL AMERICA.   WE PROPOSE TO SUPPORT SOME LIMITED FIELD EFFORT IN 2023 IN MEXICO TO SPECIFIC

SINCE 1999 HAWAIIAN GREEN SEA TURTLES HAVE BASKED IN NUMBERS ON LANIAKEA BEACH, OAHU. THIS BEACH, BEING VERY VISIBLE FROM A MAJOR HIGHWAY AND EASILY ACCESSIBLE TO VISITORS, HAS BECOME A MAGNET FOR LOCALS AND TOURISTS ALIKE. THIS THREE-YEAR GRANT OPPORTUNITY WILL ALLOW MALAMA NA HONU TO CONTINUE HAWAIIAN GREEN SEA TURTLE EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH ACROSS THE ISLAND OF OAHU, ENABLING THE ORGANIZATION TO CONTINUE TO EXPAND THEIR OVERALL EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS TO INCLUDE OUTREACH AT LANIAKEA, NESTING, BOAT STRIKE, SCHOOLS, AND OVERALL COMMUNITY OUTREACH.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING FUNDING TO THE HAWAII MARINE MAMMAL ALLIANCE FOR THE PROJECT ENTITLED "HAWAIIAN MONK SEAL MANAGEMENT SUPPORT, FIELD RESPONSE, AND OUTREACH ON MOLOKAI". HAWAIIAN MONK SEALS (HMS) ARE ONE OF THE MOST ICONIC AND BELOVED MARINE PROTECTED SPECIES IN HAWAII, HOWEVER, ARE VERY VULNERABLE TO KEY THREATS THAT ARE CHALLENGING THEIR RECOVERY. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR FIELD RESPONSE, ESCALATED (DIRECTED) SURVEYS/RESPONSE, INTERVENTIONS AND STRANDINGS OF HMS; FIELD-BASED COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT; AND A FOR HOTLINE RESPONSE, TRIAGE, DISPATCH, MULTI-AGENCY COORDINATION, INFORMATION COLLECTION AND TRANSFER, AND REPORTING.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING FUNDING TO THE MARINE MAMMAL CENTER FOR THE PROJECT ENTITLED "STRENGTHENING HAWAIIAN MONK SEAL RESPONSE AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT ON HAWAII ISLAND". THE LAST SURVIVING SPECIES IN ITS GENUS, HAWAIIAN MONK SEALS (NEOMONACHUS SCHAUINSLANDI) ARE ONE OF THE MOST ENDANGERED SEAL SPECIES IN THE WORLD. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO PROMOTE THE RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES THROUGH HAWAIIAN MONK SEAL RESPONSE AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT ON HAWAI'I ISLAND. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO FILL A CAPACITY NEED FOR SEA TURTLE RESPONSE IN WEST HAWAI'I ISLAND.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING FUNDING TO THE MARINE MAMMAL CENTER FOR THE PROJECT ENTITLED "BUILDING HAWAIIAN MONK SEAL RESPONSE AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT ON MAUI ISLAND". THE LAST SURVIVING SPECIES IN ITS GENUS, HAWAIIAN MONK SEALS (NEOMONACHUS SCHAUINSLANDI) ARE ONE OF THE MOST ENDANGERED SEAL SPECIES IN THE WORLD. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO PROMOTE THE RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES THROUGH RESPONSE AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT ON MAUI ISLAND.

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING FUNDING TO THE HAWAII WILDLIFE FUND FOR THE PROJECT ENTITLED "HOOKIPA HONU WATCH, OUTREACH EDUCATION AND MONITORING OF MAUI'S MOST SIGNIFICANT BASKING TURTLE SITE". HOOKIPA BEACH PARK IS ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT BEACH PARKS ON MAUI'S NORTH SHORE, BOTH FOR HUMAN USAGE AND FOR THE THREATENED GREEN SEA TURTLE (CHELONIA MYDAS). THE PRIMARY GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO INCREASE THE SURVIVAL OF THE HAWAIIAN GREEN SEA TURTLES THAT BASK AND NEST AT MAUI S HOOKIPA BEACH PARK BY PROTECTING THEM FROM HUMAN DISTURBANCE WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY EDUCATING THE PUBLIC ABOUT HOW THEY CAN HELP WITH THIS EFFORT.

HAWAIIAN HAWKSBILL TURTLES (ERETMOCHELYS IMBRICATA) REPRESENT ONE OF THE WORLD'S MOST ENDANGERED SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS AND A RECENT STUDY INDICATED THAT AN AVERAGE OF ONLY 14 NESTING FEMALES AND 48 NESTS ARE DOCUMENTED ACROSS THE ARCHIPELAGO EACH YEAR. NONETHELESS, THE STUDY WAS LARGELY DEPENDENT ON DATA COLLECTED FROM HAWAI'I ISLAND AND RECENT MONITORING CARRIED OUT IN 2018 AND 2021 AT HALAWA BEACH PARK ON MOLOKA'I ISLAND SUGGEST THE SITE MIGHT BE THE SINGLE-MOST IMPORTANT HAWKSBILL NESTING BEACH IN THE STATE OF HAWAI'I. THIS THREE-YEAR PROPOSAL SEEKS TO IMPROVE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AT HALAWA DURING THE 2022-2025 NESTING SEASONS WITH A FOCUS ON SOLIDIFYING THE PROJECT'S INITIAL SUCCESSES AND INITIATING NEW, HIGH-PRIORITY RESEARCH ACTIVITIES INCLUDING NIGHT MONITORING TO IDENTIFY AND QUANTIFY NESTING FEMALES, AS WELL AS POST-HATCHING NEST EXCAVATIONS TO CONFIRM NESTS, CALCULATE HATCHING SUCCESS, AND MAXIMIZE HATCHLING SURVIVAL. COMBINED, THESE ACTIVITIES WILL GENERATE URGENTLY NEEDED D

THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) IS PROVIDING FUNDING TO THE HAWAII PREPATORY ACADEMY (HPA) FOR THE PROJECT ENTITLED "HAWAII MARINE WILDLIFE RESPONSE AND EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH". THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF SEA TURTLES IN HAWAII BY OPERATING A STRANDING PROGRAM THAT COVERS THE COAST FROM UPOLU POINT TO HONOKOHAU HARBOR ON HAWAII ISLAND. HPA WILL RECEIVE, VET AND DOCUMENT PUBLIC REPORTS AND RESPOND AS APPROPRIATE TO INCLUDE FIELD RESPONSE AND ACTION TO MEDIATE THE PROBLEM. HPA WILL FACILITATE AND DELIVER RAPID AND EFFECTIVE RESPONSE TO REPORTED TURTLE STRANDINGS, INJURIES AND OTHER SITUATIONS, AND PROVIDE EDUCATION AND ADVOCACY FOR SEA TURTLES WITH LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS, VISITORS, AND RESIDENTS ALIKE.

HAWAIIAN MONK SEALS AND SEA TURTLES ARE SOME OF THE MOST ICONIC AND BELOVED MARINE PROTECTED SPECIES IN HAWAII, HOWEVER, ARE VULNERABLE TO KEY THREATS THAT ARE CHALLENGING THEIR RECOVERY. THIS PROJECT, ENTITLED "HAWAIIAN MONK SEAL AND SEA TURTLE MANAGEMENT SUPPORT, FIELD RESPONSE, AND OUTREACH ON OAHU" WILL ADDRESS FOUR KEY GOALS: (1) PROVIDE CAPACITY TO SUPPORT FIELD RESPONSE, ESCALATED (DIRECTED) SURVEYS/RESPONSES, INTERVENTIONS AND STRANDINGS FOR HAWAIIAN MONK SEALS AND SEA TURTLES, (2) SUPPORT EFFECTIVE COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND COLLABORATION, (3) MAINTAIN STAFF AND VOLUNTEER CAPACITY, TRAINING PROGRAMS AND OPERATIONAL PROCEDURES, AND (4) BUILD EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATIONS AND REPORTING PROTOCOLS.

THE PROPOSED WORK WILL PROVIDE A COLLABORATIVE INVESTIGATION TO IMPROVE LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION FOR THIS DATA-POOR SPECIES IN SUPPORT OF PROVIDING COMPREHENSIVE LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION ON YELLOWTAIL SNAPPER FROM PUERTO RICO, ST. THOMAN, AND ST. JOHNS FOR TWO UPCOMING STOCK ASSESSMENTS. THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) INVESTIGATE AGE, GROWTH, AND MORTALITY OF YELLOWTAIL SNAPPER FROM THE MANAGEMENT PLATFORMS; AND 2) DOCUMENT REPRODUCTIVE BIOLOGY FOR YELLOWTAIL SNAPPER, INCLUDING SIZE- AND AGE-AT-SEXUAL MATURITY, REPRODUCTIVE SEASONALITY, AND REPRODUCTIVE POTENTIAL/OUTPUT.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSAL IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE THEODORE ROOSEVELT CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIP (TRCP) TO HOST AN ANNUAL SALTWATER MEDIA SUMMIT IN 2022, 2023, AND 2024. THIS ANNUAL MEDIA SUMMIT DRAWS NATIONAL ATTENTION TO THE MOST PRESSING CONSERVATION ISSUES AFFECTING MARINE ECOSYSTEMS AND SALTWATER RECREATIONAL FISHING. RESULTING MEDIA COVERAGE IMPROVES THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING OF COMPLEX MARINE ISSUES AND ENHANCES NOAA'S LONG-TERM MISSION GOALS OF SUSTAINING MARINE FISHERIES, HABITATS AND BIODIVERSITY WITHIN HEALTHY AND PRODUCTIVE ECOSYSTEMS AND SUPPORTING THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY OF COASTAL COMMUNITIES

THE AGGREGATED LARGE COASTAL SHARK (LCS) GROUP CONSISTS OF SEVERAL SPECIES GOVERNED BY THE SAME RULES, BUT WE KNOW SOME OF THESE SPECIES ARE LIKELY TO BE MORE RESILIENT THAN OTHERS. FOR INSTANCE, RECENT EVIDENCE SUGGESTS HIGHLY VARIABLE POST-RELEASE MORTALITY (PRM) RATES BETWEEN LCS SPECIES IN COMMERCIAL LONGLINE FISHERIES. THIS VARIABILITY IN PRM POINTS TO A NEED FOR SPECIES-SPECIFIC STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND MANAGEMENT PLANS. AN LCS SPECIES OF PARTICULAR CONCERN IS THE SPINNER SHARK (CARCHARHINUS BREVIPINNA). SPINNER SHARKS ARE ONE OF THE MOST COMMONLY CAUGHT LCS SPECIES IN THE RECREATIONAL SHARK FISHERY AND WERE RECENTLY SHOWN TO HAVE THE HIGHEST PRM RATES OF ANY LCS SPECIES CAUGHT IN THE BOTTOM LONGLINE FISHERY. THEREFORE, SPINNER SHARKS MAY BE THE MOST VULNERABLE LCS SPECIES, REQUIRING SPECIES-SPECIFIC ASSESSMENTS AND DATA. DESPITE THIS CONCERN, AS THE BOTTOM LONGLINE FISHERY IN THE SOUTHEAST REGION DECLINES AND THE IMPACT OF RECREATIONAL FISHING IS BECOMING MAGNIFIED, NO STUDY TO DA

STOCK ASSESSMENTS RELY ON A FUNDAMENTAL UNDERSTANDING OF LIFE HISTORY (AGE, GROWTH, MATURITY, MORTALITY), BUT THIS INFORMATION REQUIRES VALIDATION AND QUALITY CONTROL TO ENSURE THE DATA PROVIDED REFLECTS STOCK DYNAMICS AND DOES NOT JEOPARDIZE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY. LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION IS OFTEN INCOMPLETE OR UNKNOWN FOR HIGHLY MIGRATORY SPECIES. THE AIM OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE A WELL-DEVELOPED REFERENCE SYSTEM FOR AGE VALIDATION OF BLUE MARLIN, BROADBILL SWORDFISH, AND NORTHERN ALBACORE TUNA TO PROVIDE VALID LIFE HISTORY CHARACTERISTICS ESSENTIAL FOR SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. A STATE-OF-THE-ART METHOD USED TO ADDRESS THESE CONCERNS CALLED BOMB RADIOCARBON (14C) DATING HAS BEEN REFINED OVER THE LAST 30 YEARS. TECHNOLOGICAL IMPROVEMENTS, COUPLED WITH INSIGHT ON PROPAGATION OF THE BOMB-PRODUCED 14C SIGNAL IN AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS, ARE NOW AVAILABLE TO RESOLVE AGE ESTIMATION ISSUES FOR CHALLENGING FISHES, AND SPECIFICALLY FOR RECENTLY COLLECTED, FAST GROWING PELAGIC FISHES. W

WE PROPOSE TO USE THE INDUSTRY-BASED HABCAM V3 TOWED CAMERA SYSTEM TO CONDUCT AN OPTICAL SURVEY OF THE ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOP (PLACOPECTEN MAGELLANICUS) RESOURCE IN THE ROTATION AREAS OF CLOSED AREA II (CA2), INCLUDING THE SOUTHEAST (SE), SOUTHWEST (SW), EXTENSION (EXT), AND THE NANTUCKET LIGHTSHIP SOUTH (NLS-S). ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL SURVEY THE OPEN BOTTOM AREAS OF THE NEW YORK BIGHT (NYB) (INCLUDING THE RECENTLY PROPOSED CLOSURE AREA), LONG ISLAND SOUND (LI), AND BLOCK ISLAND SOUND (BI).

PROJECT SUMMARY:  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE IMPACTS OF TRANSPLANTING ON SCALLOP GROWTH, DISPERSAL AND MORTALITY ADDRESSING SCALLOP RSA GENERAL RESEARCH NEEDS #4: SCALLOP RECRUITMENT SUPPLEMENTATION. THE PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE OVER ONE-YEAR PERIOD, STARTING APRIL 1ST, 2022, THROUGH MARCH 30TH, 2023. DURING THIS PERIOD, WE WILL PERFORM FIVE SURVEYS TO EVALUATE GROWTH, MORTALITY, AND DISPERSAL OF TRANSPLANTED SCALLOPS. WE PROPOSE TO MOVE 2,000 BASKETS OF SCALLOPS FROM A HARVEST SITE WITHIN TEN MILES OF THE TRANSPLANTING SITE AND ~50,000 SCALLOPS WILL BE TAGGED WITH 3/4" FLOY FLEXIBLE SHELLFISH TAGS. A SURVEY WILL BE COUNTED ONE-MONTH PRIOR TO, ONE-MONTH, THREE-MONTHS, SIX-MONTHS, AND ONE-YEAR FOLLOWING TRANSPLANT. BY TRACKING TAGGED SCALLOPS WITHIN THE TRANSPLANT SITE, WE WILL BE ABLE TO EVALUATE GROWTH AND CHANGES IN BIOMASS RELATIVE TO SCALLOPS IN A NEARBY CONTROL SITE.

DESPITE THE SPECIES BEING THOROUGHLY STUDIED AND EFFECTIVELY MANAGED, SCALLOP RECRUITMENT IS STILL POORLY UNDERSTOOD AND STRONG RECRUITMENT EVENTS ARE DIFFICULT TO PREDICT. GAINING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF SCALLOP RECRUITMENT IS IMPACTED BY THE DIFFICULTY OF IDENTIFYING LOCATIONS WHERE SPAT INITIALLY SETTLE. BARCODING OF SEDIMENTARY ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) COULD PROVIDE A METHOD FOR IDENTIFYING THE PRESENCE OF SCALLOP SPAT BEFORE THEY CAN BE IDENTIFIED USING DREDGE AND OPTICAL SURVEYS. USE OF METABARCODING, WHICH ALLOWS FOR THE IDENTIFICATION OF MULTIPLE SPECIES IN A SINGLE EDNA SAMPLE, WOULD ALSO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL SCALLOP PREDATORS, INCREASING THE VALUE OF USING THIS METHOD.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE ABILITY TO MONITOR BIOLOGICAL IMPACT (MEAT QUALITY, GROWTH AND REPRODUCTIVE POTENTIAL) TO THE ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOP AS A RESULT OF STRESS DURING AND AFTER THE DEVELOPMENT OF OFFSHORE WIND TURBINES. TO ADDRESS THIS GOAL, WE WILL LEVERAGE THE COMMERCIAL FISHERIES RESEARCH FOUNDATION'S EXISTING WIND FARM FISHERIES MONITORING SURVEY TO ESTABLISH A STANDARDIZED PROTOCOL TO DIRECTLY MONITOR BIOLOGICAL CHANGES IN THE SEA SCALLOP. THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE 1) ESTABLISH BASELINE BIOLOGICAL DATA IN THE SOUTH FORK WIND FARM DEVELOPMENT AREA AND 2) SET A PRECEDENT TO URGE THE WIND FARM COMPANIES TO INCLUDE THIS SAMPLING AS AN ESSENTIAL PIECE OF THEIR MONITORING SURVEYS.

TO EXAMINE SEA SCALLOP SURVEY DREDGE/HABITAT MAPPING CAMERA (HABCAM) PAIRED TOW DATA COLLECTED IN 2008-2009 AND FROM 2016-2021 TO CONDUCT AN UPDATED SURVEY DREDGE CATCHABILITY ANALYSIS THAT REFLECTS CURRENT RESOURCE CONDITIONS. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED IN BIOMASS ESTIMATION BY SURVEY GROUPS AND ASSESSMENT SCIENTISTS TO SCALE RELATIVE SEA SCALLOP BIOMASS TO ABSOLUTE BIOMASS FOR DREDGE SURVEYS.

IN COOPERATION WITH THE COMMERCIAL FISHING INDUSTRY, THE SCHOOL FOR MARINE SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY (SMAST) PROPOSES HIGH RESOLUTION DROP CAMERA SURVEYS IN AREAS OF THE GULF OF MAINE THAT HAVE RECENTLY BEEN OR ARE LIKELY TO BE FISHED. THIS INCLUDES AREAS SURVEYED IN 2020 AND 2021 ON STELLWAGEN BANK, JEFFREYS LEDGE, AND IPSWICH BAY WHERE EXTREMELY HIGH ABUNDANCES OF JUVENILE AND ADULT SCALLOPS PERSIST. THE RESULTING PRODUCTS INCLUDE 1) A SIZE SPECIFIC ASSESSMENT OF THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION OF SEA SCALLOPS, 2) AN ESTIMATE OF THE ABSOLUTE DENSITY (INDIVIDUALS PER M2) AND BIOMASS OF SEA SCALLOPS, 3) COMPARISONS OF SIZE, DENSITY, AND BIOMASS FROM 2018, 2020, AND 2021. THESE PRODUCTS WILL BE AVAILABLE BY EARLY AUGUST OF 2022 TO INFORM THE 2023 FISHING EFFORT DECISIONS AND AUGUST OF 2023 TO INFORM DECISION FOR THE 2024 FISHING YEAR.

TO PROVIDE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT FOR MULTIPLE GREAT LAKES STATE FISHERY PARTICIPANTS WHO WERE AFFECTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE SECRETARY OF COMMERCE APPROVED AN ADDITIONAL $15 MILLION IN APPROPRIATED FUNDS THROUGH THE CONSOLIDATED APPROPRIATIONS ACT, 2021, (THE "ACT") TO ASSIST FISHERY PARTICIPANTS AFFECTED BY THE NOVEL CORONAVIRUS IN THE GREAT LAKE STATES.  THE "ACT" AUTHORIZES FUNDS TO BE USED ONLY FOR ACTIVITIES AUTHORIZED UNDER SECTION 12005 OF THE CARES ACT, WHICH DEFINES "FISHERY PARTICIPANTS" TO INCLUDE TRIBES, PERSONS, FISHING COMMUNITIES, AQUACULTURE BUSINESSES NOT OTHERWISE ELIGIBLE FOR ASSISTANCE UNDER PART 1416 OF TITLE 7 OF THE CODE OF FEDERAL REGULATIONS FOR LOSSES RELATED TO COVID-19, PROCESSORS, OR OTHER FISHERY-RELATED BUSINESSES, WHO HAVE INCURRED, AS A DIRECT OR INDIRECT RESULT OF THE CORONAVIRUS PANDEMIC. THE COMMISSION STAFF WILL WORK WITH NOAA AND THE GREAT

THESE FUNDS WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR COASTAL AND MARINE FISHERY PARTICIPANTS NEGATIVELY AFFECTED BY COVID-19. THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS WILL RECEIVE $2,967,030 OF THIS FUNDING TO AID THE ISLAND COMMERCIAL FISHING AND AQUACULTURE INDUSTRIES. THE 5 YEAR CESU BUDGET REQUEST IS BUILT AROUND THE GOALS OF: (1) ESTIMATING THE LOSS OF BLACK ABALONE IN NUMBERS AND ALSO AS A PERCENT OF THE EXTANT POPULATION IN 2020 THAT WAS LOST AS A RESULT OF THE FIRE/FLOOD SEQUENCE THAT OCCURRED IN 2020/21 (YEAR 1) AND, (2) PROVIDING AN UP TO DATE ASSESSMENT OF THE CURRENT POPULATION SIZE, SIZE STRUCTURE AND GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF BLACK ABALONE (YEARS 2-5). YEAR 1: ESTIMATING THE LOSS OF BLACK ABALONE IN NUMBERS AND ALSO AS A PERCENT OF THE EXTANT POPULATION IN 2020, THAT WAS LOST AS A RESULT OF THE FIRE/FLOOD SEQUENCE THAT OCCURRED IN 2020/21. THIS TASK WILL UTILIZE DATA COLLECTED THIS YEAR BY THE RAIMONDI LAB. THESE DATA SETS INCLUDE ESTIMATES OF POPULATION SIZE PRIOR TO THE FIRE/RAIN EVENT OF 2020/21, PREVIOUS HABITAT SURVEYS, AND DRONE BASED IMAGERY BOTH PRE AND POST FLOOD. PROPOSAL TO CONTINUE THE SPLASH-2 EFFORT ADDRESSING CRITICAL GAPS IN NORTH PACIFIC HUMPBACK WHALES ABUNDANCE, MOVEMENTS, AND POPULATION STRUCTURE AND 2022 SAMPLING OF CENTRAL AMERICA

THE WHALE REPORT ALERT SYSTEM (WRAS) IS NOT BEING UTILIZED TO ITS FULL POTENTIAL TO REDUCE CUMULATIVE EFFECTS OF ACOUSTIC AND PHYSICAL DISTURBANCE CREATED BY LARGE COMMERCIAL VESSELS. THE QUIET SOUND WORKING GROUP SEEKS TO EVALUATE THE CURRENT UTILIZATION OF WRAS AND THEN STRENGTHEN IT THROUGH MORE ROBUST PARTICIPATION VIA INCREASED DATA INPUT, ULTIMATELY RESULTING IN INCREASED USE OF WRAS AND ASSOCIATED BENEFICIAL CHANGES IN HOW LARGE COMMERCIAL VESSELS OPERATE AROUND SRKWS.  THE OVERALL GOAL FOR THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE EFFICACY AND SCALABILITY OF THE WRAS THROUGH CROSS-BORDER AND CROSS-SECTOR COLLABORATION. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE AND ENCOURAGE ADOPTION ACROSS WASHINGTON COMMERCIAL OPERATORS IN ORDER TO EXPAND USE AND MINIMIZE IMPACTS TO WHALES IN THE SALISH SEA

WHITE ABALONE (HALIOTIS SORENSENI), A NOAA SPECIES IN THE SPOTLIGHT, IS ON THE BRINK OF EXTINCTION IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, USA AND BAJA CALIFORNIA, MEXICO. WILD POPULATIONS ARE DECLINING RAPIDLY WITH CURRENT POPULATION ESTIMATES OF < 4,100 ABALONE REMAINING (CATTON ET AL. 2016). THE WHITE ABALONE CAPTIVE BREEDING PROGRAM, HOUSED AT UC DAVIS BODEGA MARINE LABORATORY, HAS PRODUCED THOUSANDS OF WHITE ABALONE OUTPLANTED INTO THE OCEAN AND TENS OF THOUSANDS MORE DISTRIBUTED AMONG A DOZEN PARTNER FACILITIES FOR GROW-OUT, RESEARCH, AND OUTREACH. HOWEVER, THE THREE HEAT EXCHANGER SYSTEMS CRITICAL TO THIS PRODUCTION, WHICH WERE INHERITED INTO THIS PROGRAM IN 2011 FROM A PREVIOUS PROJECT ON SALMON  AND WHICH ARE CRITICAL TO ANIMAL LIFE SUPPORT  ARE FAILING, PUTTING CAPTIVE PRODUCTION AT RISK. ONE OF THESE HEAT EXCHANGERS HAS BEEN REPLACED, AND THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS FUNDS REPLACE THE OTHER TWO, PREVENTING A FUTURE CATASTROPHIC LOSS DUE TO EQUIPMENT FAILURE, AS WELL AS SUPPORTING
PUERTO RICO FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR FISHERY PARTICIPANTS PROVIDE BY CONSOLIDATED APPROPRIATIONS ACT, 2021 (P.L. 116-260). SECOND ROUND.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO  IMPROVE AUTOMATED CLASSIFICATION OF BENTHIC HABITATS IN HABCAM IMAGERY AND INCORPORATE AUTOMATED MEASUREMENT OF TARGET ORGANISMS, INCLUDING SCALLOP SHELL HEIGHT MEASUREMENTS, INTO THE VIAME SYSTEM. VIAME (VIDEO AND IMAGE ANALYTICS FOR MARINE ENVIRONMENTS) IS AN OPEN-SOURCE SYSTEM FOR ANALYSIS OF UNDERWATER IMAGERY DEVELOPED BY KITWARE, INC. WITH SUPPORT FROM THE NOAA ADMINISTRATION AUTOMATED IMAGE ANALYSIS STRATEGIC INITIATIVE. IT ALSO PROPOSES TO INVESTIGATE HABITAT PREFERENCES OF PRE-RECRUIT SCALLOPS AND  WILL USE HABCAM IMAGERY COLLECTED OVER MULTIPLE YEARS IN CLOSED AREA II AND THE SOUTHERN FLANK OF GEORGES BANK AND IN THE ELEPHANT TRUNK AND HUDSON CANYON ACCESS AREAS IN THE MID-ATLANTIC. SIZE-SELECTIVE SCALLOP DETECTORS WILL BE USED TO LOCATE PRE-RECRUIT SCALLOPS (<35MM), AND WHEN SURVEY TRACKS FROM SUCCESSIVE YEARS COVER THE SAME AREA, OVERLAPPING IMAGES WILL BE EXAMINED TO DETERMINE IF THESE SCALLOPS REMAINED IN THE AREA BY LOOKING FOR SHIFTS IN

MODIFIED PROJECT GOAL: THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE FISHERY RESOURCE MANAGERS, MARINE SCIENTISTS, AND FISHING COMMUNITIES WITH AN INDEPENDENT ASSESSMENT OF THE US GEORGES BANK SEA SCALLOP RESOURCE AND ITS ASSOCIATED HABITAT IN 2021 AND 2022.   OBJECTIVES AND DELIVERABLES:       SIZE SPECIFIC ASSESSMENT OF THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION OF SEA SCALLOPS: THE RESULTING PRODUCTS INCLUDE 1) SPATIAL SPECIFIC ESTIMATES AND ASSOCIATED ERROR OF SCALLOP SIZE THROUGHOUT RESOURCE AND 2) MAPS OF EXPLOITABLE AND JUVENILE SCALLOP DISTRIBUTIONS AT THE TIME OF THE SURVEY.         ESTIMATE OF THE ABSOLUTE DENSITY (INDIVIDUALS M2) AND BIOMASS OF SEA SCALLOPS:  THE RESULTING DATA PRODUCTS INCLUDE 1) SPATIALLY SPECIFIC ESTIMATES AND ASSOCIATED ERROR OF SCALLOP DENSITY THROUGHOUT RESOURCE, 2) MEAN MEAT WEIGHT (G) OF INDIVIDUALS OVER ENTIRE RANGE OF SCALLOP RESOURCE DERIVED FROM SHELL HEIGHT (MM) FREQUENCIES AND SHELL HEIGHT TO MEAT WEIGHT REGRESSIONS SPECIFIED BY THE NEW ENGLAND FISHER

THE PROPOSED WORK FOCUSES ON A SCALLOP DREDGE CONSERVATION ENGINEERING APPROACH TO MITIGATE THE IMPACT OF THE FISHERY ON A SUITE OF BYCATCH SPECIES, WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON WINDOWPANE AND YELLOWTAIL FLOUNDER. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, WE WILL TEST THE EFFICACY OF SAFETYNET TECHNOLOGY PISCES LED LIGHTS STRATEGICALLY AFFIXED TO THE DREDGE AND TWINE TOP TO REDUCE FINFISH BYCATCH RELATIVE TO AN IDENTICAL CONTROL DREDGE WITHOUT LIGHTS TESTED IN A PAIRED EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN. WE WILL EVALUATE SCALLOP, AS WELL AS FINFISH CATCH OVER THREE CRUISES TO GEORGES BANK (GB), TARGETING AREAS AND TIMES THAT WILL PROVIDE AN INCREASED OPPORTUNITY TO ENCOUNTER A RANGE OF BYCATCH SPECIES, ESPECIALLY YELLOWTAIL AND WINDOWPANE FLOUNDER. IN ADDITION TO THE EVALUATION OF COMPARATIVE CATCH DATA, WE WILL RECORD AND EVALUATE THE BEHAVIORAL RESPONSES OF FINFISH TO THE EXPERIMENTAL LIGHT CONFIGURATIONS VIA UNDERWATER VIDEO.

THE PROPOSED STUDY WILL SAMPE STATIONS WITHIN THE MA RESOURCE AREA AND WILL BE SURVEYED BY SIMULTANEOUSLY TOWING A STANDARD NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE (NMFS) SEA SCALLOP SURVEY DREDGE AND A COONAMESSETT FARM TURTLE DEFLECTOR DREDGE (CFTDD). THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY WILL BE TO ASSESS THE ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF SEA SCALLOPS IN THIS AREA, CULMINATING WITH SPATIALLY EXPLICIT ESTIMATES OF TOTAL AND EXPLOITABLE BIOMASS. FROM THE SAME SAMPLES, SECONDARY PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE: 1. FINFISH BYCATCH SPECIES COMPOSITION AND CATCH RATES, 2. SCALLOP BIOLOGICAL SAMPLING (LENGTH:WEIGHT RELATIONSHIP, DISEASE, PRODUCT QUALITY PARAMETERS, AND SHELL SAMPLES FOR AGEING), 3. SEA SCALLOP DREDGE PERFORMANCE (COMMERCIAL AND SURVEY DREDGES); AND 4. PREDATOR SPECIES COMPOSITION, CATCH RATES, AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION INFORMATION.

THIS PROJECT WILL PILOT THE RESEARCH FLEET APPROACH IN THE ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOP (PLACOPECTEN MAGELLANICUS) FISHERY. THE APPROACH ENGAGES AND UTILIZES FISHERMEN THROUGH THE COLLECTION OF MISSING DATA KEY TO THE IMPROVEMENT OF ANNUAL HARVEST ALLOCATION AND STOCK. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE SCALLOP INDUSTRY TO DEVELOP A COST AND TIME EFFECTIVE AT-SEA DATA COLLECTION PLATFORM AND SAMPLING PROTOCOLS TO ENABLE THE FLEET TO COLLECT BIOLOGICAL DATA FROM INDIVIDUAL SCALLOPS YEAR-ROUND. THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH FLEET, IF PRACTICAL FOR THIS FISHERY, IS TO OPERATE AS A FISHERY DEPENDENT SURVEY COLLECTING DATA IN A NEAR REAL TIME, TARGETED, SCIENTIFIC WAY TO SUPPORT FISHERIES MANAGEMENT AND STOCK ASSESSMENT. THIS RESEARCH FLEET HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BECOME A LONG-TERM FISHERY DEPENDENT SURVEY TOOL.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE THE FISHING EFFICIENCY AND FEASIBILITY OF USING THE N-VIRO DREDGE IN THE SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND LIMITED ACCESS GENERAL CATEGORY (LACG) AND LIMITED ACCESS (LA) SEA SCALLOP (PLACOPECTEN MAGELLANICUS) FISHERIES TO REDUCE BYCATCH, MINIMIZE HABITAT IMPACTS, AND IMPROVE FUEL EFFICIENCY. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE THE SCALLOP CATCH EFFICIENCY OF THE N-VIRO DREDGE THROUGH SCALABLE MODIFICATIONS AND TRIALS WITH LAGC VESSELS BEFORE TARGETING AN AREA WITH LARGE SCALLOPS AND COBBLE BOULDER SUBSTRATE WITH A LA VESSEL. SUCCESSFUL RESULTS COULD LEAD TO A TOOL FOR THE LA FISHERY TO ACCESS THE PRODUCTIVE NORTHERN EDGE OF CLOSED AREA II, OR OTHER AREAS WHERE THERE ARE LARGE HARVESTABLE SCALLOPS INTERMIXED WITH JUVENILE SCALLOPS THAT REQUIRE PROTECTION FROM HARVEST.

THE CURRENT DREDGE CONFIGURATIONS USED TO HARVEST ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOPS (PLACOPECTEN MAGELLANICUS) ALLOW SOME BYCATCH TO ESCAPE, BUT SOME NON-TARGET ANIMALS ARE STILL RETAINED. PRELIMINARY RESULTS SUGGEST THAT THE MODIFIED CUTTING BAR FROM A PREVIOUSLY FUNDED RSA PROJECT, SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCED BYCATCH OF SAND DOLLARS, SMALLER SEA SCALLOPS, AND FINFISH WITHOUT REDUCING CATCH OF MARKET-SIZE SCALLOPS. SIDE-BY-SIDE VIDEO COMPARISON SHOWED HIGHER TURBULENCE BEHIND THE CUTTING BAR ON THE MODIFIED DREDGE RELATIVE TO THE STANDARD DREDGE AT ALL TESTED ANGLES. THIS TURBULENCE APPEARED TO BE EJECTING SMALL SEA SCALLOPS, SAND DOLLARS, AND FINFISH THROUGH THE ROOF OF THE TWINE TOP BEFORE REACHING THE CHAIN BAG. THIS MODIFICATION TO THE SCALLOP DREDGE COULD SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE BYCATCH AND INCREASE CATCH EFFICIENCY. HOWEVER, FURTHER TESTING IS NEEDED TO EVALUATE HOW THE MODIFICATION PERFORMS OVER A WIDER RANGE OF FISHING CONDITIONS AND BYCATCH SPECIES. WE PROPOSE TO EXPAND TESTING OF THIS GEAR BY US

THIS APPLICANT PROPOSES TO LAY OUT A RESEARCH PLAN FOR THE DEVELOPMENT, TESTING, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A DEEP LEARNING CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORK IMAGE ANALYSIS SYSTEM FOR RAPIDLY DETECTING MONKFISH (LOPHIUSAMERICANUS) FROM OPTICAL SEABED IMAGES USING PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED ANNOTATED AND UNANNOTATED IMAGES (FIG. 1). THE RESULTING DEEP LEARNING BASED CONVOLUTIONAL NEURAL NETWORK (CNN) DETECTIONSYSTEM HAS DIRECT APPLICATION TO MONKFISH RESEARCH PRIORITIES #2 "STUDIES OF STOCK STRUCTURE/STOCK IDENTIFICATION AND IMPLICATIONS FOR STOCK ASSESSMENT AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT" #4 "COOPERATIVE RESEARCH SURVEYS TO SUPPLEMENT CURRENT SURVEY COVERAGE" AND WILL HELP ENABLE EXPANDED ANALYSIS OF EXISTING IMAGE DATA SETS AND FACILITATE IMPLEMENTATION OF REAL-TIME/NEAR-REAL TIME ANALYSIS OF IMAGES FROM TOWED (I.E. HABCAM/DROP CAMERA) AND AN AUTONOMOUS UNDERWATER VEHICLE SYSTEMS (AUV) (FIG. 2).
NO-COST EXTENSION (PRIOR APPROVAL WAIVED - RESEARCH)

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO PROVIDE FISHERY RESOURCE MANAGERS, MARINE SCIENTISTS AND FISHING COMMUNITIES WITH AN INDEPENDENT ASSESSMENT OF THE US SEA SCALLOP RESOURCE AND ITS ASSOCIATED HABITAT WITHIN SELECTED AREAS OF THE GULF OF MAINE. THESE AREAS INCLUDE TWO AREAS THAT WERE FISHED IN 2019, IPSWICH BAY AND STELLWAGEN BANK, AND TWO AREAS THAT HAVE HISTORICALLY SUPPORTED FISHING, PLATTS BANK AND JEFFERYS LEDGE IN 2019. WE WILL ALSO CONDUCT AN EXPERIMENT COMPARING AND CONTRASTING THE CENTRIC SYSTEMATIC AND STRATIFIED RANDOM SURVEY DESIGNS.SIZE SPECIFIC ASSESSMENT OF THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION OF SEA SCALLOPS: THE RESULTING PRODUCTS INCLUDE 1) SPATIAL SPECIFIC ESTIMATES AND ASSOCIATED ERROR OF SCALLOP SIZE WITHIN THE AREAS OF INTEREST AND 2) MAPS OF OVERALL, PRE-RECRUIT SIZED (<35MM SHELL HEIGHT),RECRUIT SIZED (35-75 MM SHELL HEIGHT), AND LARGER THAN RECRUIT SIZED SCALLOP DISTRIBUTIONS AT THE TIME OF THE SURVEY. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO INVESTIGATE THE IMPACTS OF OCEAN ACIDIFICATION AND WARMING ON THE ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOP FISHERY BY: (1) CONDUCTING A FIELD SURVEY OF GEORGES BANK ROTATIONAL MANAGEMENT AREAS TO CREATE A HIGH RESOLUTION MAP OF THE PRESENT-DAY CARBONATE CHEMISTRY (I.E., PH,OC, ETC.) AND THERMAL ENVIRONMENT OF THE ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOP FISHING GROUNDS, AND EXAMINE THE LINKS BETWEEN ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONAND MEAT CONDITION AT THESE SITES; (2) INCORPORATING THE SIMULATED FUTURE CARBON CHEMISTRY AND PREVIOUSLY MEASURED EFFECTS OF OCEAN ACIDIFICATION AND WARMING INTO A MODEL THAT ASSESSES THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOP BIOMASS AND LANDINGS, AND (3) INTEGRATING THE COLLECTED ENVIRONMENTAL DATA INTO THIS MODEL TO UNDERSTAND HOW OCEAN ACIDIFICATION AND WARMING WILL DIFFERENTIALLY IMPACT FISHERIES PRODUCTIVITY WITHIN THE REGIONAL MANAGEMENT AREAS ON GEORGES BANK.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO QUANTIFY SCALLOP GROWTH AND EVALUATE ITS SPATIO-TEMPORAL VARIABILITY IN THE NORTHERN GULF OF MAINE.POPULATION DYNAMICS MODEL-BASED STOCK ASSESSMENTS COUPLED WITH LARGE-SCALE AND CONSISTENT MONITORING EFFORTS CONTRIBUTE TO THE OVERALL SUCCESS OF THE ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOP (PLACOPECTEN MAGELLANICUS) FISHERY ON THE NORTH AMERICAN EAST COAST. THUS, BOTH RELIABLE STOCK ASSESSMENT AND EFFECTIVE SURVEY PROGRAMS ARE KEY IN DEVELOPING SUSTAINABLE SCALLOP FISHERIES. THIS PROPOSAL ADDRESSES ONE OF THE 2020-2021 SCALLOP RSA PRIORITIES: RESEARCH ON SCALLOP BIOLOGY, WHICH IS CRITICAL IN PROVIDING BEST AVAILABLE SCIENTIFIC ADVICE FOR SUSTAINABLEMANAGEMENT OF SCALLOP STOCK. ALTHOUGH GROWTH INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE FROM MOST AREAS, THE GROWTH DATA FROM THE NORTHERN GULF OF MAINE (NGOM) ARE LIMITED AND USUALLY EXCLUDED FROM THE ASSESSMENT FOR THE SCALLOP RESOURCE. LIMITED MONITORING EFFORTS AND AN OVERALL LACK OF INFORMATION REGARDING GROWTH IN THIS REGION HAVE LED TO LARGE UNCER

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO CONDUCT A HIGH RESOLUTION, STRATIFIED RANDOM SURVEY TO SAMPLE THE GEORGES BANK (GB) CLOSED AREA II (CAII) ACCESS AREA, AS WELL AS OPEN AREA TO THE SOUTH OF CAII COVERING THE SOUTHERN FLANK OF GB. IF THE GB CLOSED AREA I (CAI) SLIVER AREA IS OPEN TO COMMERCIAL FISHING, ADDITIONAL SURVEY STATIONS WILL BE ALLOCATED TO THIS AREA IN EITHER YEAR. APPROXIMATELY 25 STATIONS WILL BE SAMPLED IN THE CAI SLIVER, IF NEEDED, AND 100 STATIONS WILL BE SAMPLED IN THE CAII ACCESS AREA AND SURROUNDS DURING THE SURVEY IN THE SPRING/SUMMER OF 2020 AND 2021.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO HYPOTHESIZE, BASED ON PREVIOUS RESEARCH (KIRKPATRICK ET AL., 2017), AND FROM THE NATURE OF THE SPECIES AND THE FISHERY, THAT THE SEA SCALLOP FISHERY WILL BE UNIQUELY SENSITIVE TO WIND INSTALLATIONS PLACED WITHIN FISHING GROUNDS. INDEED, SPATIAL ANALYSES PERFORMED BY THE REGIONAL WIND TEAM FROM THE GREATER ATLANTIC REGIONAL FISHERIES OFFICE/NORTHEAST FISHERIES SCIENCE CENTER THAT ARE BASED ON VESSEL TRIP REPORT DATA SHOW OVERLAP OF PROPOSED WIND ARRAYS AND SCALLOP FISHERY HOTSPOTS, AND FARM INSTALLATIONS LOCATED ACROSS THE DIRECT TRANSIT ROUTE THAT PROVIDES ACCESS TO THE HOTSPOTS. LIKEWISE, THE POTENTIAL FOR SEA SCALLOP HABITAT DISTURBANCE DUE TO WIND ARRAY INSTALLATION HAS ALSO BEEN NOTED (GUIDA ET AL., 2017). THESE ANALYSES AND PROJECTED POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF OFFSHORE WIND DEVELOPMENT UNDERPIN OUR OBJECTIVE, TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW OFFSHORE WIND ENERGY INFRASTRUCTURE MAY DIRECTLY AFFECT THE ECONOMICS OF THE ATLANTIC SEA SCALLOP FISHERY THROUGH CHANGES I

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO USE AGE BASED ASSESSMENT IN THE SEA SCALLOP PLACOPECTEN MAGELLANICUS. THE SCALLOP (PLACOPECTEN MAGELLANICUS) FISHERY IS ASSESSED WITH A CASA LENGTH STRUCTURED MODEL AND A LENGTH AND SPATIALLY STRUCTURED PROJECTION MODEL (SAMS -SCALLOP AREA MANAGEMENT SIMULATOR). THIS ASSESSMENT/PROJECTION FRAMEWORK HAS SERVED THE FISHERY WELL OVER THE PAST TWO DECADES AS DEMONSTRATED BY ITS STATUS AS THE SECOND MOST VALUABLE FISHERY (AFTER LOBSTERS) ON THE U.S. ATLANTIC COAST. CURRENTLY, THE SCALLOP RESOURCE IS NOT OVERFISHED AND OVERFISHING IS NOT OCCURRING. WHY ADD AN AGE BASED ELEMENT TO THE CURRENT LENGTH-BASED APPROACH? THE COMBINED APPROACH TRACKS THE POPULATION SIMULTANEOUSLY IN TERMS OF AGE AND LENGTH AND ADDITION OF AGE DATA IS THE NEXT LOGICAL STEP IN EVOLUTION OF IMPROVED MODELS FOR SEA SCALLOPS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO CONDUCT A RESOLUTION, STRATIFIED RANDOM SURVEY TO SAMPLE THE NANTUCKET LIGHTSHIP. APPROXIMATELY 135 STATIONS WILL BE SAMPLED DURING THE SURVEY ON AN ANNUAL BASIS IN THE SPRING/SUMMER OF 2020 AND 2021. THE PROJECT PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A FINE SCALE STRATIFIED RANDOM DREDGE SURVEY IN THE NLCA DURING THESPRING/SUMMER OF 2020 AND 2021. THE SURVEY AREA IS SIMILAR TO THE AREA VIMS HAS SURVEYED IN 2016,2017, 2018, AND 2019. MODIFICATIONS TO THE SURVEY DOMAIN OVER THE YEARS HAS BEEN A RESULT OF DISCUSSIONS WITH THE NEFSC AND CHANGES TO SAMS AREAS WITHIN THE SURVEY DOMAIN. THE SURVEY DOMAIN WILL INCLUDE ALL RELEVANT SAMS AREAS AS DESIGNATED BY THE SCALLOP PDT AND CAN BE MODIFIED TO ACCOUNT FOR ANY CHANGES TO SAMS AREAS MADE BETWEEN YEARS. STRATIFICATION IS BASED ON THE NEFSC SCALLOP STRATA.
